s01_story__core__content:
Angel Knoverek built MindShift Center's trauma-responsive mindfulness approach after years of seeing a painful pattern: highly capable adults and caregivers were being told to "just breathe," "sit still," or "meditate through it," only to become more activated, flooded, or ashamed when their nervous systems didn't cooperate.

As a counselor educator and licensed clinician, Angel repeatedly watched clients and students struggle most between sessions and outside the therapy room—during work meetings, while driving, at bedtime, and in the middle of parenting or conflict. The problem wasn't a lack of willpower. The problem was that most mindfulness tools weren't designed for hyperarousal physiology.

Over time, she clarified a safer path: start with consent, pacing, and clear stop/modify/reset rules; teach a plain-language map of hyperarousal; give discreet in-the-moment interruption tools that do not require eyes closed or breath focus; then build stability over time with a minimum effective daily routine.

Trauma-Responsive Mindfulness for Hyperarousal became an 8-module, step-by-step course that prioritizes safety-first practice design, nervous-system clarity, and real-life usability. The program includes guided audio options (including short 3–5 minute practices), downloadable worksheets/trackers, and optional support tiers so learners can stay private or add accountability without pressure to share personal details.
s02_offer__core__investment_terms: $297 USD; payment plan available; 30-day money-back guarantee.
s02_offer__core__short_description: An 8-module trauma-responsive mindfulness course for adults with hyperarousal, panic sensations, rumination, and hypervigilance—built for real life with short guided practices, worksheets, and optional support tiers.
s02_offer__core__unique_mechanism_descri: A trauma-responsive, hyperarousal-specific pathway that starts with consent and safety rules, teaches a plain-language nervous-system map, and gives multiple non-breath-focused mindfulness entry points plus a stop/modify/reset protocol—so practice builds capacity instead of triggering flooding.
s02_offer__core__delivery_format: Self-paced online course with short videos, guided audio downloads (including 3–5 minute options), and downloadable worksheets/trackers; optional stepped support tiers (community, group Q&A, 1:1 coaching).
s02_offer__core__delivery_access: Lifetime course access with updates; mobile-friendly.
s02_offer__core__delivery_community: Optional moderated community, anonymous Q&A, and no-sharing-required norms; private mode supported.
s02_offer__core__delivery_advisory: Educational, skills-based mindfulness and nervous-system regulation program; not psychotherapy, not medical advice; does not diagnose/treat/cure/prevent conditions; not crisis care; in the U.S. call/text 988 for crisis support.
s02_offer__feature_01__description: I start with clear safety rules, opt-outs, and a stop/modify/reset protocol so I know exactly how to stay within my capacity.
s02_offer__feature_02__description: I learn ethical guardrails and simple nervous-system education so I can name patterns without shame or confusion.
s02_offer__feature_03__description: I leave with daily practices and real-time tools I can use when my body hijacks me—without requiring breath focus.
s02_offer__feature_04__description: I get mini-guides for nighttime spirals so I'm not guessing at 2 a.m. and I can return to rest faster.
s02_offer__feature_05__description: I learn to spot likely triggers in standard mindfulness and choose safer alternatives like eyes-open orientation, sensory anchors, and movement.
s02_offer__feature_06__description: I use checklists, flowcharts, and simple trackers that help me notice recovery time and patterns without obsessing over perfection.
s02_offer__feature_07__description: I get an immediate win by following the minimum effective routine on low-bandwidth days so I can stay consistent without burnout.
s02_offer__feature_08__description: I can learn via short videos and guided audios with options that match my capacity—from quick resets to longer practices when I'm ready.
s02_offer__feature_09__description: I can equip myself with discreet steps for work, driving, parenting, and conflict so I can function during real-life stress.
s02_offer__feature_10__description: I can join moderated Q&A or community when I want accountability, while keeping privacy boundaries and no pressure to share.
s03_pains__pain_01__title: Stuck in constant hyperarousal with no off-switch
s03_pains__pain_01__description: I can't tell if my struggle is anxiety, trauma activation, or something else, but when hyperarousal hits it feels like my body takes over and I can't reliably come down.
s03_pains__pain_01__quote_01: I feel stuck trying to come down once my body flips into overdrive.
s03_pains__pain_01__quote_02: I'm tired of bracing for the next spike like my system is a ticking time bomb.
s03_pains__pain_01__quote_03: I need a clear plan for what to do the moment I feel that surge start.
s03_pains__pain_02__title: My body feels unsafe and unpredictable
s03_pains__pain_02__description: I dread how quickly my body interprets normal sensations as danger, and it makes me hypervigilant, tense, and mistrustful of myself.
s03_pains__pain_02__quote_01: I'm afraid my body sensations mean danger and I'll lose control.
s03_pains__pain_02__quote_02: I wake up with my nervous system already scanning for what could go wrong.
s03_pains__pain_02__quote_03: I want peace in my body instead of treating every sensation like a threat.
s03_pains__pain_03__title: Meditation and breath focus make me worse
s03_pains__pain_03__description: I keep falling back into fear because generic mindfulness tells me to focus on breath or sit in silence, and that can trigger panic or dissociation for me.
s03_pains__pain_03__quote_01: I do well for a while, and then one breath-focused practice makes me spiral again.
s03_pains__pain_03__quote_02: I've confessed to myself that meditation apps have made me feel trapped and panicky.
s03_pains__pain_03__quote_03: I need the root issue addressed: my system gets more activated when I focus inward the wrong way.
s03_pains__pain_04__title: Nighttime rumination and 2 a.m. spirals ruin sleep
s03_pains__pain_04__description: I'm afraid it will be like this forever because my mind ramps up at night, I spiral into obsessive thinking, and I can't get the rest I need.
s03_pains__pain_04__quote_01: I don't want bedtime to feel like the start of a mental marathon.
s03_pains__pain_04__quote_02: I'm scared of the 2 a.m. spiral because it wrecks the next day and makes everything harder.
s03_pains__pain_04__quote_03: I'll only move forward if I have something I can do in the moment when my thoughts won't shut off.
s03_pains__pain_05__title: Progress slips between therapy sessions or after therapy ends
s03_pains__pain_05__description: I've had breakthrough moments, especially in therapy, but without a daily structure I drift, relapse, and feel like I'm rebuilding from scratch.
s03_pains__pain_05__quote_01: I got free once in therapy, and then life got stressful and I slipped back.
s03_pains__pain_05__quote_02: Without daily practices, I lose momentum between sessions and I feel like I'm starting over.
s03_pains__pain_05__quote_03: I need a simple maintenance system so progress feels durable, not fragile.
s03_pains__pain_06__title: I don't know what's safe to do when I'm activated
s03_pains__pain_06__description: I want something that is explicitly trauma-responsive, with clear stop/modify/reset steps so I know what to do if a practice increases distress.
s03_pains__pain_06__quote_01: I won't engage unless I know exactly what to do if a practice makes me feel worse.
s03_pains__pain_06__quote_02: I need clear protocols for stop, modify, and reset so I can stay within my window of tolerance.
s03_pains__pain_06__quote_03: I want a process that keeps me safe and gives me choices, not a one-size-fits-all routine.
s03_pains__pain_07__title: Low bandwidth makes consistency feel impossible
s03_pains__pain_07__description: I get lost in theory or perfectionism, and then I quit; I need short practices and a minimum effective path that works even when I'm exhausted.
s03_pains__pain_07__quote_01: I don't have hours to meditate or journal, especially on hard days.
s03_pains__pain_07__quote_02: I learn best with short, guided options and a minimum effective path I can actually follow.
s03_pains__pain_07__quote_03: I want to know exactly what matters most so I don't quit from overwhelm.
s03_pains__pain_08__title: I need trauma-responsive help that complements therapy/meds
s03_pains__pain_08__description: I'm in therapy and/or using medication, and I need tools that complement my care and respect boundaries instead of making me feel pressured or unsafe.
s03_pains__pain_08__quote_01: I want help that respects my therapy and doesn't tell me to ditch my provider or meds.
s03_pains__pain_08__quote_02: I need clarity on when I should pause, get support, or seek a higher level of care.
s03_pains__pain_08__quote_03: I'm looking for complement tools that fit alongside my treatment plan, not compete with it.
s03_pains__pain_09__title: Privacy concerns keep me from joining groups
s03_pains__pain_09__description: I don't want my participation visible or my personal details exposed, so I avoid groups unless privacy and moderation are crystal clear.
s03_pains__pain_09__quote_01: I want the option to learn privately without being seen or having to share personal details.
s03_pains__pain_09__quote_02: I need assurance that community is optional and boundaries are enforced.
s03_pains__pain_09__quote_03: I prefer discreet participation with clear moderation and confidentiality norms.
s03_pains__pain_10__title: I want a reproducible model to help others safely (clinicians/leaders)
s03_pains__pain_10__description: I want to help others safely, but I need a clear, scope-appropriate model with decision points for when to stop, refer, or recommend additional support.
s03_pains__pain_10__quote_01: I need a reproducible model I can trust when I'm supporting others who are dysregulated.
s03_pains__pain_10__quote_02: I want clear stop/refer guidance so I stay in ethical scope and protect people's safety.
s03_pains__pain_10__quote_03: I'm looking for tools and language I can use in psychoeducation without turning it into therapy.
s04_desires__desire_01__title: To come down from hyperarousal without forcing calm
s04_desires__desire_01__vision_snapshot: I notice the first signs of activation and use a short reset; I stay functional without forcing myself to be perfectly calm.
s04_desires__desire_01__tangible_milesto: I track 30, 60, and 90 days of using an in-the-moment spike plan and I can see my recovery time shortening.
s04_desires__desire_01__emotional_win: I feel relief and quiet confidence because I know what to do when activation starts, and I don't have to panic about panicking.
s04_desires__desire_01__quote_01: I want to live free from the constant on-edge feeling and know how to downshift when it starts.
s04_desires__desire_01__quote_02: I'm ready to measure progress by faster recovery, not perfect calm.
s04_desires__desire_01__quote_03: I crave the calm confidence of knowing I can handle a spike if it happens.
s04_desires__desire_02__title: To understand my nervous system in plain language
s04_desires__desire_02__vision_snapshot: I can discern normal stress from hyperarousal patterns because I have a simple map and I can name what's happening without panic.
s04_desires__desire_02__tangible_milesto: I complete the triage tool for my activation cues and I can name my top triggers and my earliest body signals.
s04_desires__desire_02__emotional_win: I feel secure because I can name what's happening in my nervous system and respond instead of spiraling into fear and self-blame.
s04_desires__desire_02__quote_01: I want clarity about what hyperarousal is so I stop feeling confused and scared.
s04_desires__desire_02__quote_02: I'm done guessing what's happening in my body and blaming myself.
s04_desires__desire_02__quote_03: I love knowing exactly why my system reacts and what to do next.
s04_desires__desire_03__title: To trust my body's sensations again
s04_desires__desire_03__vision_snapshot: I experience consistent body trust: sensations rise and fall, and I treat them like information instead of alarms.
s04_desires__desire_03__tangible_milesto: I mark 90 days of treating sensations as information and I can tolerate body cues with less fear and reactivity.
s04_desires__desire_03__emotional_win: I feel proud that my body sensations are becoming information again, not an emergency that runs my life.
s04_desires__desire_03__quote_01: I want freedom that holds my body with kindness instead of fear.
s04_desires__desire_03__quote_02: I'm ready to close the gap between sensations and panic by rebuilding body trust slowly.
s04_desires__desire_03__quote_03: I long to be able to feel sensations without instantly interpreting them as danger.
s04_desires__desire_04__title: To practice mindfulness safely without breath-focus or eyes-closed pressure
s04_desires__desire_04__vision_snapshot: I follow a process that doesn't require eyes closed, long silence, or breath focus; I stay oriented and in control the whole time.
s04_desires__desire_04__tangible_milesto: I complete the Safety Module and I can list at least five eyes-open, non-breath-focused options I trust.
s04_desires__desire_04__emotional_win: I feel at peace because my practice respects my limits, gives me options, and doesn't force me into triggering methods.
s04_desires__desire_04__quote_01: I want a conservative approach to mindfulness that prioritizes safety over intensity.
s04_desires__desire_04__quote_02: I'm looking for a method that works even if breath focus and eyes closed are triggering for me.
s04_desires__desire_04__quote_03: I value dignity and choice in how I practice—no pressure, no forcing.
s04_desires__desire_05__title: To follow a simple daily regulation routine that actually fits my life
s04_desires__desire_05__vision_snapshot: I practice simple, sustainable routines in 3–5 minutes on hard days, and I expand when I have capacity without pressure.
s04_desires__desire_05__tangible_milesto: I check off daily disciplines on a minimum effective routine for 14 days without needing perfection or long sessions.
s04_desires__desire_05__emotional_win: I feel steady because I finally have a routine that fits my bandwidth and I can restart without shame when life happens.
s04_desires__desire_05__quote_01: I want a plan that fits my real life, including my lowest-bandwidth days.
s04_desires__desire_05__quote_02: I'm excited to see what happens when I do 3–5 minutes consistently instead of all-or-nothing.
s04_desires__desire_05__quote_03: I love having checklists and a minimum effective routine so I can follow through.
s05_authority__core__title: PhD counselor educator and licensed clinician; Associate Professor & Director of Counselor Education; President of the Missouri Counseling Association; Co-Chair of NCTSN Complex Trauma/DTD Work Group
s05_authority__historical_01: Ph.D. in Counselor Education & Supervision (earned in 2012 at Regent University)
s05_authority__historical_02: Licensed Professional Counselor (Missouri) and Licensed Clinical Professional Counselor (Illinois); Approved Clinical Supervisor (ACS)
s05_authority__historical_03: Associate Professor of Counselor Education and Director of Counselor Education at Culver-Stockton College
s05_authority__historical_04: Clinical faculty in Counselor Education at Adams State University (faculty directory listing)
s05_authority__historical_05: President of the Missouri Counseling Association (MCA) and involved in its reestablishment effort (public news release)
s05_authority__credentials_01: Co-Chair of the National Child Traumatic Stress Network (NCTSN) Complex Trauma/Developmental Trauma Disorder Work Group
s05_authority__credentials_02: Listed by NCTSN as an Individual Affiliate (Illinois)
s05_authority__credentials_03: Program contact for CACREP 'in process' M.A. programs at Culver-Stockton College (CACREP listing)
s06_competitors__competitor_01__offering: Mindfulness and sleep app with meditations, music, and sleep stories
s06_competitors__competitor_01__usp: Large library with strong brand recognition and sleep-focused content
s06_competitors__competitor_02__offering: Meditation and mindfulness app with structured courses
s06_competitors__competitor_02__usp: Beginner-friendly programs and strong UX with guided series
s06_competitors__competitor_03__offering: Meditation app with large free library and paid courses
s06_competitors__competitor_03__usp: Massive variety of teachers and practices with a large free tier
s06_competitors__competitor_04__offering: Meditation app and courses emphasizing practical, skeptical-friendly mindfulness
s06_competitors__competitor_04__usp: Plainspoken teaching style aimed at practical results and skepticism
s06_competitors_indirect__competitor_01_: Access to online therapy and counseling support
Overlaps when buyers decide between skills-course support and ongoing therapy subscription
s06_competitors_indirect__competitor_02_: Overlaps for people seeking between-session support or therapy alternatives due to access barriers
s06_competitors_indirect__competitor_03_: Mental wellness coaching and behavior-change support
Overlaps as a structured app-based option for stress/anxiety management routines
s07_audience__demographics__gender: Skews female but balanced; significant male participation
s07_audience__demographics__education: Some college to graduate/professional degrees; therapy-literate and interested in practical psychoeducation
s07_audience__demographics__occupation: Professionals (education, healthcare, admin, tech, service); caregivers/parents; some clinicians-in-training or helpers seeking skills
s07_audience__demographics__location: Primarily United States (with strong fit for English-speaking adults globally)
s07_audience__values_01: I believe my symptoms are nervous-system responses, not character flaws.
s07_audience__values_02: I value autonomy, and I need to feel in control of pace, participation, and practice choices.
s07_audience__values_03: I believe systems beat motivation, especially when I'm exhausted or activated.
s07_audience__values_04: I think ethical support is clear about scope, safety, and realistic outcomes.
s07_audience__values_05: I believe small consistent practices compound, and micro-doses count on hard days.
s07_audience__interests_01: I spend evenings trying to calm my mind and body, especially when rumination kicks in at night.
s07_audience__interests_02: I invest in therapy, books, and courses when they feel grounded and practical, not trendy or performative.
s07_audience__interests_03: I care about sleep, routines, and small habits because my stability affects everything else in my life.
s07_audience__interests_04: I look for discreet tools I can use in public without drawing attention to myself.
s07_audience__interests_05: I'm interested in nervous-system education that helps me stop blaming myself for symptoms.
s08_values__synthesis: If you asked me what I stand for, I'd say: 'I want safety-first tools that give me real choices, protect my dignity, and help me build steady capacity over time—without hype, shame, or pressure to share my story.'
s08_values__value_01__explanation: I believe in being honest about what I'm experiencing without pretending I'm fine. I want language that tells the truth without scaring me or shaming me.
s08_values__value_02__explanation: I see setbacks as information, not proof that I'm failing. I want a process that helps me build capacity over time with small, repeatable steps.
s08_values__value_03__explanation: I value ethical guidance with clear boundaries and honest claims. I want support that avoids manipulation, exaggeration, or pressure tactics.
s08_values__value_04__explanation: I need to be in charge of my pace and my participation. I want clear opt-outs and stop/modify/reset instructions so I can practice without getting overwhelmed.
s08_values__value_05__explanation: I want to be treated like a whole person, not a problem to fix. I respond best to kindness that still gives me practical direction.
s08_values__value_06__explanation: I keep going when things get hard, but I need a structure that supports restarts. I value consistency that doesn't require perfection.
s08_values__value_07__explanation: I want my stability to improve my relationships and the way I show up for others. I value tools that help me be more present at home and at work.
s09_transformation__before: Before finding this solution, I was stuck in hyperarousal and nighttime spirals, afraid of my body, and discouraged because meditation made me feel worse.
s09_transformation__after: Now I have a clear system that works: safety-first choices, a spike plan, and short daily practices that help me recover faster and feel more steady.
s09_transformation__emotional_shift: I've gone from feeling trapped and ashamed to feeling more agency, dignity, and realistic hope.
s09_transformation__impact: This transformation has given me back my time and attention. I don't spend all day bracing for the next spike, and when my system ramps up I have steps that help me recover faster and feel more in control.
s10_media__podcasts_03__name: Ten Percent Happier with Dan Harris
s11_objections__objection_01__objection: I don't have time to learn a whole new system
s11_objections__objection_01__rebuttal: This is designed for real life and low bandwidth: you'll get 3–5 minute options and a minimum effective path so you can practice without adding another overwhelming commitment.
s11_objections__objection_02__objection: I've tried similar things before and they didn't work
s11_objections__objection_02__rebuttal: The difference is trauma-responsiveness: clear opt-outs, eyes-open options, alternatives to breath focus, and a stop/modify/reset protocol so you're not forced into what has made you worse before.
s11_objections__objection_03__objection: The price is too high for me right now
s11_objections__objection_03__rebuttal: Continuing in cycles costs more than it seems—lost sleep, productivity hits, and constant bracing add up. This is a structured skillset you can reuse long-term, and payment plans help contain risk.
s11_objections__objection_04__objection: I'm not sure this will work for my specific situation
s11_objections__objection_04__rebuttal: Issue-specific playbooks and multiple practice pathways mean you can adapt the tools to your triggers, your environment, and your capacity—without a one-size-fits-all protocol.
s11_objections__objection_05__objection: I need to think about it first
s11_objections__objection_05__rebuttal: Taking time is wise—start with the quick-start safety plan and one short practice, then decide based on how it feels in your body rather than trying to force readiness.
s11_objections__objection_06__objection: I'm worried this conflicts with my therapy or meds
s11_objections__objection_06__rebuttal: This complements care: it's educational skills training, not psychotherapy or medical advice, and it's designed to fit alongside therapy and medication with clear boundaries and referral guidance.
s12_advantage__uvp_01: Only system specifically designed for hyperarousal when standard mindfulness is activating
s12_advantage__uvp_02: Combines a clear 8-module pathway with guided audio, worksheets, and stepped support tiers
s12_advantage__uvp_03: Progress measured by recovery time and capacity-building, not perfection or long sits
s12_advantage__uvp_04: Ethical, scope-clear positioning as education and skills training—not therapy or crisis care
s12_advantage__uvp_05: Fulfillment on-ramp includes safety foundations, quick-start options, and private-mode participation
s12_advantage__comparison: Unlike programs that dump generic meditations and tell me to 'just breathe,' this course starts with safety rules, offers multiple non-breath-focused entry points, and gives a step-by-step spike plan plus a minimum effective routine built for high activation.
s12_advantage__innovation: We pioneered the hyperarousal-specific, trauma-responsive mindfulness pathway with stop/modify/reset protocols and eyes-open alternatives to breath focus as a core design, not an afterthought.
s13_comms__tone: Warm, steady, and validating—like talking to a calm and knowledgeable guide who understands what it's like to live with high activation.
s13_comms__style: Plain language, clear steps, and practical framing; normalizes symptoms; avoids clinical jargon and hype.
s13_comms__vibe: Empowering yet realistic: normalizes symptoms, treats setbacks as data, and emphasizes choice and pacing.
r01_brand_style__typography__headings__d: Clean, modern sans-serif for headlines and section titles
r01_brand_style__typography__body__descr: Friendly, readable sans-serif for body text and UI elements
r01_brand_style__visual_style__approach: Calm, professional, and approachable—minimal clutter, ample whitespace, and soft gradients
r01_brand_style__voice__description: Warm expert guide: confident but not pushy, validating without coddling, practical without being cold
